text: Have people had issues with installing CairoMakie at all? I'll be updating some tutorial code that currently uses pyplot and I'm wondering if it's "safe" to switch to Makie when it comes to everyone being able to use it

elements.text: Have people had issues with installing CairoMakie at all? I'll be updating some tutorial code that currently uses pyplot and I'm wondering if it's "safe" to switch to Makie when it comes to everyone being able to use it

text: I have found it pretty reliable so far, that's because if Cairo works, CairoMakie pretty much works, and that has been good ever since binarybuilder added cairo

text: The students may not have Julia knowledge (or much programming knowledge) so I  want things to just work for them. I know people have issues with GLMakie from time to time, but if that's just GLMakie then I think it's fine

text: it's a pity that glmakie is so flaky, for example I still can't close windows reliably on Mac, which seems to be a glfw problem. And that library is maintained by one person it seems. So I can relate that they don't have time. But still

text: Hiding all xticklabels except for one panel was quite difficult in R, for example. In Makie, very easy

text: I may try to get MakieTex back online for the course, I'll probably need it sooner or later. Or is there a different plan for tex labels now?

elements.text: I may try to get MakieTex back online for the course, I'll probably need it sooner or later. Or is there a different plan for tex labels now?

text: No, but it would be optimal to handle within the `text` primitive, I think. Because then we could just dispatch in a few selected places to latex stuff if we encounter a LatexString. For that, we'd need the latex layout algorithm in Julia that GR and matplotlib use, and some logic to have separate latex fonts, because the layout algorithms will be dependent on those.

elements.text: No, but it would be optimal to handle within the
text

primitive, I think. Because then we could just dispatch in a few selected places to latex stuff if we encounter a LatexString. For that, we'd need the latex layout algorithm in Julia that GR and matplotlib use, and some logic to have separate latex fonts, because the layout algorithms will be dependent on those.

text: Or we roundtrip with real latex, but that will always be slow. And I wouldn't want to rewrite Axis so that it can take arbitrary plot objects for tick labels etc...

elements.text: Or we roundtrip with real latex, but that will always be slow. And I wouldn't want to rewrite Axis so that it can take arbitrary plot objects for tick labels etc...

text: MakieTex used images with crazy high resolution last time I looked at it

elements.text: MakieTex used images with crazy high resolution last time I looked at it

text: "latex layout algorithm" sounds complicated to me... I think getting MakieTex working again (if it doesn't anymore - I have no idea) would be a good first step. We could probably use latexstrings in AbstractPlotting and replace that in the backends instead, if changing axis is too much of a hassle

elements.text: "latex layout algorithm" sounds complicated to me... I think getting MakieTex working again (if it doesn't anymore - I have no idea) would be a good first step. We could probably use latexstrings in AbstractPlotting and replace that in the backends instead, if changing axis is too much of a hassle

text: George's statement isn't 100% correct. We have this problem still open: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/cairomakie-and-fontconfig/55931/5>

attachments.text: I have seen some issues with scaled or rotated glyphs when switching back and forth between GLMakie and CairoMakie. But not totally wrong order or placement like here. Is there anything threaded going on? Probably not right

text:
I remember talking about this with Simon a couple of months ago...
Iirc the issue is that Cairo's transform matrix is the same as the font libraries and if it's not reset you get this kind of stuff. Though I thought we fixed that
